response_parsed.title: Deep Dive: ZoneInfo Standard Library Module in Python 3.12+
response_parsed.summary: This explainer provides a comprehensive overview of the ZoneInfo standard library module introduced in Python 3.12, focusing on its functionalities and key features for managing time zones accurately.
key_points: The ZoneInfo module replaces the outdated tzlocal and pytz modules
It provides a consistent API for working with time zones across Python versions
ZoneInfo supports IANA time zone database (olson database) directly
Improved performance due to built-in support in C
Simplified handling of daylight saving time transitions

code_examples.code:
from datetime import datetime, timezone

utc = datetime(2023, 3, 15, tzinfo=timezone.utc)
nyc = utc.astimezone(timezone('America/New_York'))

from zoneinfo import ZoneInfo

us_east_coast = ZoneInfo('America/New_York')

version_notes: For backward compatibility, tzlocal and pytz modules are still available but deprecated
Check the official documentation for more information on upgrading from older versions
caveats: Although ZoneInfo provides a consistent API, some functionality may vary between tzlocal and pytz
Ensure that you update any dependencies using the appropriate package manager (e.g., pip) before upgrading to Python 3.12
